metadata.title: Activating colloidal synthesized Au catalyst by the electrochemical strategy: Gas atmosphere, electrolyte and electrochemical technique

All rights are reserved, including those for text and data mining, AI training, and similar technologies. 2024-09-18T08:03:44.326Z http://vtw.elsevier.com/data/voc/AddOnTypes/50.7/aggregated-refined Zhejiang Provincial Natural Science Foundation of China LQ20B030011 ZJNSF Zhejiang Province Natural Science Foundation http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/SciValFunders/501100004731 http://sws.geonames.org/1814991 surface of Au NPs 46,47 National Natural Science Foundation of China 22202054 NSFC National Natural Science Foundation of China http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/SciValFunders/501100001809 http://sws.geonames.org/1814991 CV was used to remove thiol ligand from the surface of Au NPs. Although CV has been frequently used to activate electrocatalysts before catalytic tests, there is few research on the detailed process of CV activation, so we have carried out related studies. Fig. 2a is a schematic diagram of CV technology, in which several important parameters are high potential (EH), low potential (EL) and period. We used the ORR activity as an indicator for ligand removal. The initial ORR activity of ligand-capped Au/C catalyst is very poor (Fig. 2b), and its half-wave potential is 0.657 V (Fig. 2c). The CV curve in N2 shows that there is no reduction peak of Au at \u223C1.0 V, indicating that the Au surface was completely covered by the ligand (Fig. S2a). The preliminary study indicates that the thiol ligand on the surface of Au NPs can be completely removed by 20 CV periods in the potential range of 0.2 V \u2212 1.7 V in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH aqueous solution. The Au/C catalyst after ligand removal shows excellent ORR activity (Fig. 2b), and its half-wave potential is 0.820 V (Fig. 2c), which is comparable to that of other noble metal catalysts [45]. The CV curve in N2 shows an obvious redox peak of Au (Fig. S2a). The electrochemical surface area (ECSA) of Au calculated from the reduction peak of Au is 48.6 m2 g\u22121, which is close to the ECSA of 5.4 nm Au NPs with clean surface, indicating that the ligand on the surface of Au NPs has been removed. The initial ORR activity of the annealed catalyst (i.e. Au/C-350 \u00B0C, the half-wave potential is 0.789 V) is much higher than that of the Au/C catalyst without annealing, indicating that annealing can remove thiol ligand. The ORR activity of Au/C-350 \u00B0C catalyst can be further improved after CV activation (the half-wave potential is 0.802 V), showing that the ligand cannot be removed by annealing, and further CV activation is required. After CV activation, the calculated ECSA of Au/C-350 \u00B0C is 32.5 m2 g\u22121 (Fig. S2b), which corresponds to the ECSA of 7.4 nm Au NPs with clean surface, demonstrating that CV can remove the ligand. It is worth noting that both of the ORR half-wave potential and the ORR limiting-diffusion current of CV activated Au/C-350 \u00B0C catalyst are lower than that of CV activated Au/C catalyst (Fig. 2b). This may be due to the sintering of Au NPs after annealing, resulting in the reduction of the Au surface area, which can be supported by the TEM, XRD and ECSA results of Au/C and Au/C-350 \u00B0C catalysts mentioned above. It is worth noting that researchers in previous studies have found that sintering of metal NPs would improve the ORR performance (binary or multicomponent alloy system), which can be ascribed to the increasement of crystallinity and alloying degree of the alloy catalysts [46,47]. However, in our single metal system (Au NPs), sintering will only lead to the growth of NPs, thus reducing the catalytic active surface area, leading to the decline of ORR activity.This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (22202054) and Zhejiang Provincial Natural Science Foundation of China (LQ20B030011). Hangzhou 310051 PR China bZhejiang Baima Lake Laboratory Co., Ltd., Hangzhou 310051, PR China c National Demonstration Center for Experimental Light Chemistry Engineering Education, Shaanxi University of Science and Technology, Xi'an, 710021, Shaanxi, PR China National Demonstration Center for Experimental Light Chemistry Engineering Education Shaanxi University of Science and Technology Xi'an Shaanxi 710021 PR China cNational Demonstration Center for Experimental Light Chemistry Engineering Education, Shaanxi University of Science and Technology, Xi'an, 710021, Shaanxi, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Organic ligands are necessarily used to stabilize nanoparticles (NPs) in colloid synthesis, and the presence of these ligands in most cases can have adverse effects on heterogeneous nanocatalysis. Therefore, it is crucial to develop efficient methods to remove ligands and study the removal mechanism. In this article, we developed a combined electrochemical method (chronoamperometry (CA) + cyclic voltammetry (CV)), which can completely and efficiently remove thiol ligand from Au NPs to produce cleaned Au/C catalyst. Using the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activity as the evaluation criterion for ligand removal, we found that gas atmosphere (O2) plays an important role in the removal process, while the acidity and alkalinity of electrolyte have no effect on the removal efficiency. A proposed thiol ligand removal mechanism along with Au degradation is presented. The results of CA activation at an oxidation constant potential (1.7 V) indicate that oxidation of thiol alone cannot remove thiol ligand. Only if a reduction constant potential of 0.2 V is further applied, the ORR activity of Au/C catalyst will increase, indicating that both the oxidation and reduction processes of Au NPs are crucial for ligand removal. Although the CA method (with an upper potential of 1.7 V and a lower potential of 0.2 V) can efficiently remove the majority of thiol ligand, complete removal of thiol ligand requires further CV activation. Based on the relevant results, a combined electrochemical method (CA + CV) is established. Developing standardized methods for removing ligands on the surface of catalysts is important for obtaining efficient catalysts and is also important for the reproducibility of catalytic results. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ligand removal Au catalyst Oxygen reduction reaction Electrochemical strategy Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Noble metal nanoparticles (NPs, such as Au, Pt, Pd, etc.) show outstanding activity in multiple heterogeneous catalytic reactions [1-6], and colloidal synthesis is an important method for the synthesis of these noble metal NPs [7-9]. In colloidal synthesis, organic ligands (or surfactants) are indispensable [10-12]. On the one hand, ligands can control the size of synthesized NPs. For example, Puntes and co-workers [13] successfully synthesized Au NPs with uniform size of 3–15 nm by adjusting a series of parameters using sodium citrate as the ligand. On the other hand, ligands can regulate the shape of prepared NPs. For instance, Xu and co-workers [14] synthesized Au NPs with different shapes (including Au nanospheres, Au nanorods, Au nano-octahedra, etc.) by adjusting the ratio of sodium citrate and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) ligands. The successful synthesis of these NPs with different sizes or shapes provides a good platform for people to study the size effect or crystal plane effect in catalysis. However, the presence of ligands will influence the activity of catalytic reactions (inhibiting or promoting) [15], which will lead to opposite conclusion [16]. Furthermore, for most catalytic reactions, the presence of ligands is not conducive to the catalytic reaction. Therefore, in most cases, the removal of ligands is a necessary step before the activity evaluation of catalytic reactions [17,18]. For these reasons, it is very important to develop efficient methods to remove ligands from the surface of noble metal NPs. In previous studies, various methods have been developed to remove ligands from the surface of noble metal NPs. Common methods include annealing [19,20], ligand exchange [21,22], ultraviolet-ozone (UV-ozone) [23,24], electrochemical strategy [25,26], etc. Annealing and UV-ozone are mainly used to decompose organic ligands through heat or light, which will inevitably lead to oxidation or structural damage on the surface of NPs [27,28]. Ligand exchange is a process of replacing strong ligands with weak ligands to remove the original strong ligands. Theoretically, ligand exchange is incomplete [29,30]. The electrochemical strategy is a method to remove the ligands on the surface of NPs by regulating the surface state of NPs through potential. Considering the oxidation/reduction state on the surface of NPs can be freely regulated by potential, this method is an ideal method to remove the ligands from the surface of NPs. In fact, electrochemical CV activation is considered as a necessary step before electrocatalytic measurements [31-33]. However, such an important step is lack of systematic research. Furthermore, the authors of electrocatalytic research often rarely mention the pre-activation process of nanocatalysts (i.e., the detailed steps of removing ligands) in the article, leading to poor repeatability of catalytic results. Therefore, it is necessary to establish a standardized process to remove the ligands from the surface of noble metal NPs, so as to ensure the repeatability of electrocatalytic results. Among various noble metal colloidal synthesis systems, thiols protected Au NPs is a very classic system, which has been widely used in the fields of nanocatalysis, biological imaging and so on [34-39]. Thiols and Au NPs generally form Au-S bond with very strong bond energy, which is generally considered to be close to covalent bond [40]. Therefore, the removal of thiol ligands from the surface of Au NPs is often very difficult. If we can completely remove thiol ligands from the surface of Au NPs and study its removal mechanism, it can provide important reference for the removal of organic ligands from the surface of other noble metal NPs [41]. In this paper, we are surprised to discover that the thiol ligand on the surface of Au NPs can be completely and efficiently removed by a combined electrochemical method (chronoamperometry (CA) + cyclic voltammetry (CV)). Gas atmosphere (O2) and potential range play an important role in the removal process, while the acidity and alkalinity of electrolyte have no effect on the removal efficiency. A proposed thiol ligand removal mechanism along with Au degradation is displayed in this paper. Although thiol ligand can be removed only by CV, it will take a long time. The thiol ligand cannot be completely removed by CA alone, and CV is still needed for further activation to remove the remaining ligand. A combined electrochemical method (CA+CV) can completely and efficiently remove thiol ligand from Au NPs to produce cleaned Au/C catalyst. The development of standardized methods for removing organic ligands on the surface of catalysts plays an important role in obtaining efficient catalysts, and it is also of great significance for the repeatability of catalytic results. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of thiol ligand capped 5 nm Au NPs Au NPs were synthesized by a reported method with minor modifications [42]. The typical synthesis process is as follows: 100 mg of AuPPh3Cl and 400 μL of dodecanethiol were added in 20 mL of toluene to form a transparent solution, and then 176 mg of borane tert‑butylamine complex (BTBC) was added to reduce Au precursors. The mixture was stirred at 55 °C for 5 h, and then cooled to room temperature. The prepared Au NPs were precipitated by adding 20 mL of ethanol. The final Au NPs were separated by centrifuge, washed with ethanol, and dried overnight in vacuum at 60 °C. 2.2 Preparation of carbon supported catalyst A certain amount of Au NPs was dispersed in 40 mL of toluene, and the required amount of carbon support (Vulcan XC-72) was added to the solution. The mass loading of Au NPs on the carbon support was controlled at about 15%. After 6 h of stirring, the solid product was collected by centrifugation and washed twice with ethanol. The Au/C catalyst was dried in a vacuum box at 60 °C and then ground evenly. 2.3 Electrochemical measurement All electrochemical measurements were carried out at room temperature using an electrochemical workstation (CH Instruments Co., Ltd., model CHI 700E). The working electrode was a glassy carbon electrode loaded with synthesized catalyst, the reference electrode was a saturated calomel electrode (SCE), and the counter electrode was a platinum wire electrode. The SCE was separated by double reference electrode to ensure the stability of SCE in alkaline medium. The potential vs SCE was transferred to that vs reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) using the following equation: E (vs RHE) = E (vs SCE) + 0.059 × pH + 1.000 [43,44]. If not otherwise specified, all the following potentials refer to RHE. In order to prepare catalyst ink, a certain amount of catalyst was dispersed in the mixture of 750 μL deionized water, 200 μL isopropanol and 50 μL Nafion. The mixed solution was ultrasonically treated for 15 min to obtain a uniform catalyst ink. A certain amount of ink was then deposited on the surface of a rotating disc electrode with a diameter of 3 mm and dried in air. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) were used to determine the catalytic activity of different Au/C catalysts for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). CV was carried out in 0.1 M KOH solution saturated with N2 or O2 at a scanning rate of 50 mV s−1. LSV was recorded in 0.1 M KOH solution saturated with O2 at 900 rpm with a scanning rate of 10 mV s−1. The electrochemical surface area (ECSA) is calculated by the Au2O3 reduction peak through the following equation using a value of 400 μ C cm-2. E C S A = A ν · 10 6 400 · 1 m Where ECSA is in m2/gAu, A is the area of the gold oxide reduction peak (mA · V), ν is the scan rate (mV/s), m is the actual load of Au on the electrode (g). The surface coverage of ligand ( θ ) can be calculated by the following equation: θ = total Au surface area − exposed Au surface area total Au surface area = S EC − 20 − S EC − X S EC − 20 S EC-20 is the total surface area of Au NPs (20 CV periods activation in O2). S EC-X is the exposed surface area of Au NPs after CV activation in N2 or air. 2.4 Electrochemical removal of ligands CV and CA were used to effectively remove ligands from the surface of catalysts. The CV was performed in 0.1 M KOH aqueous solution saturated with O2 by scanning 20 cycles in the potential range between 0.2 V and 1.7 V (vs. RHE) at a scanning rate of 50 mV s−1. The CA activation was performed in 0.1 M KOH aqueous solution saturated with O2 by regulating different periods and interval time of CA. The high potential was set at 1.7 V and the low potential was set at 0.2 V. The ORR results were used to compare the efficiency of ligand removal. 2.5 Physical characterization of catalyst Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were collected by using an instrument of HT-7700. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on an equipment of Bruker D8 Advance with Cu Kα irradiation. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer with an Al Kα X-ray source. All XPS spectra were corrected using a 284.7 eV C1s line. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) was performed on an instrument of Agilent 7700. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Removal of ligands from Au NPs by CV We first synthesized Au NPs by colloidal synthesis and loaded them on carbon black to obtain carbon supported Au catalyst (Au/C). TEM image in Fig. 1 a shows that Au NPs are uniformly distributed on carbon black and the average particle size of Au NPs is 5.4 nm. We tried to remove thiol ligands from the surface of Au NPs by traditional annealing method (350 °C in air). The annealed catalyst is defined as Au/C-350 °C. As shown in Fig. 1b, the average particle size of Au NPs in Au/C-350 °C catalyst has grown to 7.1 nm, indicating that annealing can not only remove the organic ligands from the surface of Au NPs, but also lead to agglomeration and sintering of Au NPs, thus reducing the surface area of Au NPs (as will be proved by the following electrochemical experiments). The XRD patterns before and after annealing also proved the sintering of Au NPs (Fig. S1). CV was used to remove thiol ligand from the surface of Au NPs. Although CV has been frequently used to activate electrocatalysts before catalytic tests, there is few research on the detailed process of CV activation, so we have carried out related studies. Fig. 2 a is a schematic diagram of CV technology, in which several important parameters are high potential (EH), low potential (EL) and period. We used the ORR activity as an indicator for ligand removal. The initial ORR activity of ligand-capped Au/C catalyst is very poor (Fig. 2b), and its half-wave potential is 0.657 V (Fig. 2c). The CV curve in N2 shows that there is no reduction peak of Au at ∼1.0 V, indicating that the Au surface was completely covered by the ligand (Fig. S2a). The preliminary study indicates that the thiol ligand on the surface of Au NPs can be completely removed by 20 CV periods in the potential range of 0.2 V − 1.7 V in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH aqueous solution. The Au/C catalyst after ligand removal shows excellent ORR activity (Fig. 2b), and its half-wave potential is 0.820 V (Fig. 2c), which is comparable to that of other noble metal catalysts [45]. The CV curve in N2 shows an obvious redox peak of Au (Fig. S2a). The electrochemical surface area (ECSA) of Au calculated from the reduction peak of Au is 48.6 m2 g−1, which is close to the ECSA of 5.4 nm Au NPs with clean surface, indicating that the ligand on the surface of Au NPs has been removed. The initial ORR activity of the annealed catalyst (i.e. Au/C-350 °C, the half-wave potential is 0.789 V) is much higher than that of the Au/C catalyst without annealing, indicating that annealing can remove thiol ligand. The ORR activity of Au/C-350 °C catalyst can be further improved after CV activation (the half-wave potential is 0.802 V), showing that the ligand cannot be removed by annealing, and further CV activation is required. After CV activation, the calculated ECSA of Au/C-350 °C is 32.5 m2 g−1 (Fig. S2b), which corresponds to the ECSA of 7.4 nm Au NPs with clean surface, demonstrating that CV can remove the ligand. It is worth noting that both of the ORR half-wave potential and the ORR limiting-diffusion current of CV activated Au/C-350 °C catalyst are lower than that of CV activated Au/C catalyst (Fig. 2b). This may be due to the sintering of Au NPs after annealing, resulting in the reduction of the Au surface area, which can be supported by the TEM, XRD and ECSA results of Au/C and Au/C-350 °C catalysts mentioned above. It is worth noting that researchers in previous studies have found that sintering of metal NPs would improve the ORR performance (binary or multicomponent alloy system), which can be ascribed to the increasement of crystallinity and alloying degree of the alloy catalysts [46,47]. However, in our single metal system (Au NPs), sintering will only lead to the growth of NPs, thus reducing the catalytic active surface area, leading to the decline of ORR activity. The successful removal of thiol ligand by CV was further supported by the reverse ligand poisoning experiment. The experimental details can be seen in supporting information. As shown in Fig. S3, the ORR performance can be largely improved by 20 CV periods in the potential range of 0.2 V − 1.7 V in O2. After reverse adsorption of thiol ligand, the ORR activity of Au/C catalyst returned to the initial activity, indicating that the improvement of ORR activity was due to the removal of thiol ligand, rather than other reasons. 3.2 Effects of gas atmosphere, electrolyte and CV high potential on ligand removal efficiency by CV activation We further investigated the effects of gas atmosphere, electrolyte and CV high potential (EH) on ligand removal efficiency by CV activation. Gas atmosphere plays an important role in ligand removal. Fig. S4 shows the CV curves of Au/C catalyst under different gas atmosphere (N2, air or O2). It can be seen that the reduction peak area of Au increases with the increase of O2 concentration, indicating the importance of O2. The CV curves in N2 (Fig. 3 a) and the ORR curves (Fig. 3b) after 20 CV periods under different gas atmosphere (N2, air, or O2) also confirm that O2 plays an important role in the ligand removal process. That is, with the increase of O2 concentration, the ECSA and ORR activities of Au/C gradually increased, indicating that the ligand was gradually removed. The coverage of thiol ligand after 20 CV periods in N2 was calculated to be 89% and the coverage of thiol ligand after 20 CV periods in air was calculated to be 58% (the calculation details can be seen in the experimental section), indicating that 89% of thiol ligand was remained on the surface of Au NPs after CV activation in N2 and 58% of thiol ligand was remained on the surface of Au NPs after CV activation in air. Therefore, we believe that O2 should be involved in the removal of thiol ligand, which will be discussed below. In order to explore whether electrolyte may affect the removal of ligand, we replaced the electrolyte with acid (0.5 M H2SO4). As shown in Fig. 4 a, the initial Au/C catalyst has an invisible redox peak of Au, indicating that the Au surface was completely covered by the ligand. After 20 CV periods in the potential range of 0.2 V − 1.7 V in O2-saturated 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution, an obvious redox peak of Au appeared, and the calculated ECSA of Au was 47.5 m2 g−1, which was close to the ECSA calculated under alkaline medium, proving the removal of ligand. The ORR activity of Au/C catalyst after ligand removal also greatly improved under acidic medium (Fig. 4b). The above results show that the electrolyte does not affect the removal efficiency of CV activation. We further evaluated the effect of EH on ligand removal. When EH = 1.3 V, the ORR activity did not increase with CV scanning (Fig. S5a), indicating that 1.3 V could not remove the ligand. When EH = 1.4 V, the ORR activity gradually increased with the progress of scanning (Fig. S5b), indicating that the ligand can be removed when EH was between 1.3 V − 1.4 V, which corresponds to the potential at which Au was just oxidized (Fig. 3a). With the increase of EH, the activation efficiency by CV was better (Fig. S5b–f). We collected ORR LSV curves of Au/C in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH after CV activation from 0.2 V to different EH for 20 periods (Fig. 5 a), and found that the ORR activity achieved best when EH = 1.7 V, indicating that the ligand removal efficiency was the best. The effect of EH on CV activation can be directly observed from the change of ORR half-wave potential with EH (Fig. 5b). The above results show that O2 and EH have important effects on ligand removal, while electrolyte has no effect on the removal efficiency. 3.3 The removal mechanism of thiol ligand from Au NPs It is important to clarify the removal mechanism of thiol ligand from the surface of Au NPs. The above research shows that the optimal high limit potential for removing thiol ligand is 1.7 V, and at this potential, Au is likely to dissolve [48]. Therefore, the removal of thiol ligand may be accompanied by the dissolution of Au. Therefore, we used ICP-MS to detect the amount of Au ions in electrolyte solutions at different CV periods (5, 10, 20, and 40). As shown in Fig. 6 , with the increase of CV period, the amount of dissolved Au is gradually increasing, and the calculated proportion of Au catalyst remaining on the electrode surface is gradually decreasing. When the CV period is 20, the proportion of Au remaining on the electrode surface is about 95%, indicating that the 20 CV period causes the loss of Au by 5%, which is not very large, probably because the presence of thiol ligand protects the loss of Au. The loss of Au is reasonable, because the potential of 1.7 V is already within the range of Au oxidation potential. According to the literature [48], as long as the potential is greater than 1.4 V, Au oxidation will occur, that is, Au will absorb O atoms or hydroxide, and then Au will dissolve in the process of potential decline. In the electrolyte solution after ligand removal, we did not detect the signal of S based on ICP-MS, indicating that thiol was not oxidized to thiolate and dissolved in the solution. We speculated that thiol was replaced by O atom and lost the coordination interaction with Au, and a small amount of thiol (water-insoluble substance) separated from the electrode surface, resulting in the separation of oil phase (thiol) and water phase (electrolyte solution), so the signal of S could not be detected in the solution. We used XPS to detect the signals of Au and S of Au/C and CV activated Au/C with different CV periods (Fig. 7 ). With the increase of CV period, the binding energy of Au 4f 7/2 gradually decreases from 84.0 eV to 83.7 eV (Fig. 7a), indicating the change of the electronic structure of Au surface, which may be due to the gradual removal of thiol ligand from Au surface. According to the literature report [49], there is a weak electronic interaction between Au and S ligand, and Au will give electrons to S to show a positive valence state. With the increase of CV period, the signal of S gradually weakens (Fig. 7b), which also indicates the removal of ligand. Moreover, the peak binding energy of S basically does not change, indicating that the structure of the remaining thiol ligand does not change during the ligand removal process. Based on the above analysis, we can preliminarily draw the mechanism diagram of thiol ligand removal from Au surface. As shown in Fig. 8 , at a high potential of 1.7 V, O atoms replace thiols to form Au oxide (or hydroxide), because the interaction between Au and O is stronger than that between Au and thiol (with the help of O2). When the potential drops to 0.2 V, the Au oxide (or hydroxide) gradually becomes zero valent Au. In this process, some Au atoms are dissolved in the electrolyte solution, resulting in the loss of Au. When the potential continued to rise and fall, the thiol ligand can be gradually removed, and a small amount of Au will dissolve. 3.4 Removal of ligands from Au NPs by CA If thiol ligand can be removed by Au oxidation at a high potential. Why don't we directly give Au/C catalyst a constant oxidation potential? Thus, we kept the Au/C catalyst at a constant potential of 1.7 V for 5 s to 120 s. However, as shown in Fig. 9 a and b, such a constant high potential did not increase the ORR activity of Au/C catalyst, indicating that simply giving a high potential cannot remove the ligand. Surprisingly, when we gave a CA period (i.e., first at a high potential (1.7 V) for 5 s, and then at a low potential (0.2 V) for 5 s), the ORR activity can be significantly increased (Fig. 9a and b). This may be because the thiolate on the Au surface needs to be separated from the Au surface at a reduction potential, so as to complete the ligand removal process. Fig. 10 shows the schematic diagram of CA activation, in which several important parameters are high potential (EH), low potential (EL), period and interval time. Considering that the EH was high enough and EL was low enough, we focused on the effect of period and interval time on the efficiency of CA activation. As shown in Fig. 9c and d, 5 CA periods can achieve the best activation effect. On the premise of maintaining 5 CA periods, the best interval time is 7 s (Fig. 11 ). 3.5 The optimal route to remove ligands from Au NPs We then compared the effects of using CV or CA activation to remove the ligand. As shown in Figs. 12 a and S6, although CA activation can greatly enhance the ORR activity of Au/C catalyst, its activation effect is not as good as CV activation. If we activate the Au/C catalyst with additional 3 CV periods on the basis of CA activation, i.e. using a combination of CA + CV, the ORR activity of the activated Au/C catalyst can exceed that of pure CV activation (Figs. 12a and S6). Moreover, it only takes 180 s for CA + CV combination activation, while 1200s for CV alone (Fig. 12b), which shows that the efficiency of removing ligand by CA + CV combination is more than 6 times that by CV alone. We recovered the Au/C catalyst after ligand removal by CA + CV combination. TEM showed that Au NPs were evenly distributed with an average particle size of 5.4 nm (Fig. 13 a), which was similar to the average particle size of Au NPs in the original Au/C catalyst (5.4 nm, Fig. 1a). XPS showed that the Au/C catalyst had no S signal after activation (Fig. 13b), indicating that the thiol ligand on the surface of Au/C catalyst had been completely removed. The above results show that CA + CV combination is a mild and efficient way to remove ligands from Au NPs. 4 Conclusion In this paper, a combined electrochemical method (CA + CV) is developed to completely and efficiently remove thiol ligand from Au NPs to produce cleaned Au/C catalyst. Gas atmosphere (O2) and potential range play an important role in the removal process, while the acidity and alkalinity of electrolyte have no effect on the removal efficiency. Based on ICP-MS and XPS, the thiol ligand removal mechanism along with Au degradation is explored in this article. Au-S bond has very strong bond energy and is generally considered to be close to covalent bond. The removal of thiol ligand from the surface of Au NPs is often very difficult. Therefore, the efficient ligand removal method introduced in this paper can provide important reference for the removal of organic ligands from the surface of other noble metal NPs, such as Pt, Pd, Ru, Rh, etc. Recently, we are expanding this method to remove different ligands from the surface of Pt and Pd NPs, which will be published in the near future. coredata.dc:description: Organic ligands are necessarily used to stabilize nanoparticles (NPs) in colloid synthesis, and the presence of these ligands in most cases can have adverse effects on heterogeneous nanocatalysis. Therefore, it is crucial to develop efficient methods to remove ligands and study the removal mechanism. In this article, we developed a combined electrochemical method (chronoamperometry (CA) + cyclic voltammetry (CV)), which can completely and efficiently remove thiol ligand from Au NPs to produce cleaned Au/C catalyst. Using the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activity as the evaluation criterion for ligand removal, we found that gas atmosphere (O2) plays an important role in the removal process, while the acidity and alkalinity of electrolyte have no effect on the removal efficiency. A proposed thiol ligand removal mechanism along with Au degradation is presented. The results of CA activation at an oxidation constant potential (1.7 V) indicate that oxidation of thiol alone cannot remove thiol ligand. Only if a reduction constant potential of 0.2 V is further applied, the ORR activity of Au/C catalyst will increase, indicating that both the oxidation and reduction processes of Au NPs are crucial for ligand removal. Although the CA method (with an upper potential of 1.7 V and a lower potential of 0.2 V) can efficiently remove the majority of thiol ligand, complete removal of thiol ligand requires further CV activation. Based on the relevant results, a combined electrochemical method (CA + CV) is established. Developing standardized methods for removing ligands on the surface of catalysts is important for obtaining efficient catalysts and is also important for the reproducibility of catalytic results.
